sentences.sentence: Medical opportunity Effective treatments for COVID-19 could help to rebrand an industry that consistently rates at the bottom of public opinion polls.At the height of its influence a few decades ago, the pharmaceutical sector enjoyed the highest profit margins of any industry.

Movies such as Love & Other Drugs stand alongside blockbusters like The Social Network in documenting industries that became cultural touchstones.Much like technology today,legislators and regulators have long scrambled to catch up and rein in drug manufacturers.

"Pharma was the perfect test case that celebrated markets, but is fine with concentrations of power and monopoly," laments economics historian Edward Nik-Khah.The delivery of effective treatments for COVID-19, be they vaccines or plasmapheresis, has the potential tore-invent the industry as a model for collaboration and shared purpose.This is especially significant for a sector that consistently rates at the bottom of public opinion polls.In its origins in the 19th century, American pioneers such as Charles Pfizer and Eli Lilly called their products "ethical drugs", to differentiate their wares from those offered by snake-oil peddlers.It wasn't until the arrival of penicillin and its successful global distribution that pharmaceuticals were able to throw off their reputations as pushers of addictive or shonky drugs.

Instead they were able to rebrand themselves as producers of innovative, lifesaving products.But recent decades have seen scandal after scandal, especially around the malevolent influence over doctors and medical evidence.

They have varied from faulty hip prostheses, to diagnoses invented to market medications and, most recently, the excessive prescription of opioids.A member of the family that owns Purdue Pharma, the firm behind the drug OxyContin, was a key marketing brain who helped fuel the rise of big pharma.

Decades ago Arthur Sackler, a doctor turned advertising executive, coined the strategies of Medicine Avenue, a play on Madison Avenue's status as the beating heart of global advertising.Over several decades this fuelled what long-term industry critic Ray Moynihan calls "well-organised medical imperialism".
"The entanglement of pharma and the medical industry leads to distortion of research and diagnosis."

says Moynihan, now an academic at Bond University focused on overdiagnosis.But the potential of successful COVID-19 treatments may herald a modern version of penicillin for the industry, especially in terms of public relations.

A company such as AstraZeneca has minimal history of developing vaccines, but now sits at the forefront of the scientific-industrial establishment in its collaboration with Oxford University.Despite Britain and the US being heavily criticised for inadequate responses to the spread of COVID-19, history may judge them to have had the best strategies in terms of biomedical solutions.
It was in Britain that the use of dexamethasone to minimise the worst symptoms of the virus was perfected, while the antiviral drug remdesivir was created in the US.

"Their response to the pandemic and this great work that pharma people are doing reminded many of their capacities and how they can be helpful to the world - as opposed to the industry being viewed as selfish and unco-operative."
Bill Gates told Fortune magazine.Our local players are less maligned, given companies such as CSL are among the most celebrated in Australian industry.

The billions of dollars in extra funding to help with advanced manufacturing could also help to expand the production of medical devices and biotechnology.Elizabeth de Somer, the chief executive of Medicines Australia, hopes the current moment can entrench collaboration across the sector.
"The difference here is more open sharing with governments and other companies.

Public benefit outweighs other considerations," she says.De Somer hopes such collaboration may be also prove to be a model for other intractable problems such as climate change, breaking through the inertia of political and financial barriers.Medical science is undoubtedly among the greatest achievements of mankind.

Much like any potential vaccine, fair and equitable distribution has always been a political challenge.Chronic diseases such as arthritis, diabetes and mental health had replaced infectious diseases as the focus of healthcare in rich countries.
But pesky microbes have the power to alter history.

The novel coronavirus has thrust back infectious disease as the centrepiece of health and the economy.There is the risk such urgency may only sustain the worst practices of big pharma, from profiteering to the corruption of medical evidence.

But there is a greater promise of the successful development and distribution of any COVID-19 treatments.The pharmaceutical industry has a chance to lead industry and to reinvigorate belief in scientific capitalism.Tanveer Ahmed is a practising psychiatrist.

documents.result_message: Our detector is moderately confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
